summary: Woody, Buzz Lightyear and the rest of the gang embark on a road trip with Bonnie and a new toy named Forky. The adventurous journey turns into an unexpected reunion as Woody's slight detour leads him to his long-lost friend Bo Peep. As Woody and Bo discuss the old days, they soon start to realize that they're worlds apart when it comes to what they want from life as a toy.

As a Toy Story and Woody fan, I was so excited for this film to be released(mostly because of the iconic way the trailer included God Only Knows by the Beach Boys) and it did NOT disappoint me. The way they took Woody's constant self analysis of his life's purpose and brough it to a final resolution like that was phenomenal. I had personally always seen these themes deep in Woody's character, and I am so thankful they explored them in this way. All those lines about not knowing what he was if not a child's toy made me cry in the theaters. this was one of those movies where the whole audience left the theater with brand new personalities and new views of life. Truly a great finale to the Toy Story series and an exceptional study of Woody's character. 10/10 would recommend.

It's fun while watching it, but afterwards you kinda just feel empty. Toy Story 3 was a good ending to the franchise, and although I originally wanted a sequel, this movie was completely unnecessary. The movie is full of details that contradict the first three, and the original characters have all been sidelined to make way for all the new merchandise (which is really all they are at this point). Of what we actually saw of the original characters, it's clear that Pixar had no idea what they were doing and just ruined them. Buzz is a complete idiot, relying only on his voice chip for direction. Jessie has no longer gotten over fear of small dark spaces, and nearly has a panic attack sitting is a fairly lit closet WITH all the other toys. Rex's only purpose is to scream at misfortune, Dolly is a complete jerk, Mr Potato Head being quiet is understandable since Don Rickles died, but that doesn't mean that Hamm and Slinky should be silent as well. And the worst one of all is Woody. His character was so mangled that he isn't even loyal to his kid any more, and he is also dummed down to make Bo Peep be in the spotlight more. And last but not least, Forky. Need I say more? (well yes this is a review after all) Forky's existence breaks the whole franchise. He should not be alive because he is not a toy. I probably have more things to say, but I have to go so bye

I was very disappointed when I saw Toy Story 4 for the first time. And I'm going to be blunt, when I saw it a 2nd time, I completely dispised this movie. I will never understand how so many people liked this movie. Bo Peep is completely out of character for how she was in the first 2 films. I'm not talking about when we meet her again half way into the film, I'm talking from the very first minute of the film. The original toys literally get cast aside for all the new characters, including Jessie! Buzz has been reduced to an idiot who only knows how to push buttons on his chest. Woody completely turns his back on his kid to run off with Bo Peep, who treats Woody horribly mind u. Constantly talking down to him every chance she gets. Forky becoming a sentient toy completely breaks the rules and logic of the Toy Story-verse. The villain is completely evil who tried to rip out Woodys voice box, and when that doesn't work she manipulates him in order to get what she wants.....and she's rewarded for it. Sid, Stinky Pete, and Lotso all received some sort of punishment for their actions, but Gabby received no such repercussion. This movie is a joke. All the magic from the original trilogy is gone. The only small positive I'll give this movie, is the animation is great. So congrats, u went from a half a Star, to 1 full star rating for me. In my opinion, this film sucks, avoid it at all costs!!!

Pretty great! I love the originality and touchingness Pixar can still bring to the films. The animation is continually getting better, however, unfortunately, the storylines are getting more modern. They are incorporating love stories and other dull modern-day jokes that some kids may not understand too well. I almost don't want a Toy Story 5, inferring that it might stray too far off the path of stardom the older movies have barely been clinging on to. One other thing I like is that the franchise doesn't really try to subtly "vanish" characters from the movies over the years. Not many characters are forgotten, and if they are, they make a comeback later. For instance, even Sid is in Toy Story 4 as a garbage truck driver. Really. The charmingness is very touching, and I enjoyed the extent of the movie.

Much of the beloved characters were pushed to the side and seemed dumbed down. Especially Buzz who went from leading a gang to save woody in Toy Story 2, to using his toy mechanics to tell him what to do. It also felt like a lot of the movie were side joke fillers rather than plot/character development.
While very unnecessary, Toy Story 4 is a well-told, emotional film with the best comedy Pixar has to offer. A fresh and new direction makes for a fun movie for the entire family.

I remember first hearing about this movie coming out, I felt confused and a bit displeased. Toy Story 3 to me at the time had the best ending I've ever seen in a movie and a 4th installment to that franchise to me felt like it was threw away the significance of the epilogue of Toy Story 3. To my surprise this movie isn't just a typical Disney cash grab like some of their movies, this was very well done, even for a movie that I thought was unnecessary. It even had a tender, heartwarming ending as well as Woody parts ways with his old friends to live as a free spirit with his old friend and possibly romantic interest in Bo Peep and befriending her crew. Most would think that would be the perfect way to cap off a wildly successful franchise but hey, that's what I thought about Toy Story 3 and I've been proven wrong about that so we'll see how it all goes a few years if a 5th installment is made. Either way, Toy Story has left an illustrious legacy and has nothing else left to prove.

Toy Story 4 is the latest installment to the highly successful Pixar franchise. This film series has improved through the years in terms of animation, story, character development and world-building. It has given us several endearing characters that made us laugh and cry. It's no surprise that this new sequel lives up to our expectations. It's still very funny, heartwarming and adventurous! It will make you laugh and tug at your heartstrings like the movies that came before it. It's also notable that the 3D animation itself has vastly improved since the very first movie. The characters that we've grown to love have been looking better and better with each sequel. Kudos to the writers for always coming up with witty and clever stories that are also exciting and unpredictable. Toy Story is definitely one of Pixar's best creations, it not THE best. I love how they've introduced new lovable characters in this movie. I also like how they've showcased Bo Peep, even if they had to cut back on Buzz's exposure. And as usual, the movie has a few moral lessons to impart on us. Some of these lessons are obvious and some are hidden. And like its predecessors, Toy Story 4 is going to make you smile, laugh and even shed a tear.

Animation is stunning as always and a testament to how far Pixar has come since the original Toy Story. This is a movie, that even now I still can't really make my mind up about. Like, I enjoyed it, I'm giving it a positive review, but it's easily the weakest of the entire franchise, and I actually don't think it's that close. The biggest problem is that this isn't a "Toy Story" movie; it's a movie completely about Woody. Everything is around him, not the rest of the toys. Because it's the fourth film I guess they can do that, but imagine if like a seven year old went with his or her family to watch this movie. They'll like it, but are they going to remember characters like Jessie, Bullseye, and the rest of the gang like the other three films? No, they're just not. In the other three films it felt like the screen time for all the characters were perfectly balanced. In this movie, however, again, it's all about Woody. Another big thing is that the new characters are really either a hit or a miss for me. Like I love Duke Caboom, but not really that tiny officer toy thing. It's like the same thing that Toy Story 3 has, just more of a distraction, at least for me. Now, with all of that said, this is a really enjoyable movie to watch. Animation is great, I like the story enough, but what's not talked about is the setting. Putting this story in a carnival was such a smart idea, and it can lead to a lot of good "action" shots. So yeah, I'm recommending it, just don't expect the same impact the other films had. There was really only one scene that left a huge impact for me, and without going into spoilers, it involved Gabby Gabby, the villain. I would put on a lot more Pixar movies before this one, but I wouldn't mind taking this one out of the toy box every now and a then. Go to Disney+ and make you're own opinion on this probably ending of arguably the best animated franchise ever!

I have no problem with it being a Woody movie but the movie is called Toy Story. With this I did expect the story to be about Woody and the toys not just mostly Woody himself. Sure the new characters like Forky, Gabby Gabby, Ducky and Bunny, and Duke Kaboom were memorable and fun to watch it just would've been more entertaining with the other toys that are there. However despite the movie's flaws there's a lot that I enjoy in this one. I enjoy Woody and Bo Peep's relationship. I actually enjoyed the father figure between Woody and Forky and I also enjoyed Bonnie experiencing school for the first time. However my favorite thing about this movie is the ending. I just loved how this movie ended. I really like the idea of Woody doing what he wants for wants he really wants to be with Bo Peep and he finally gets to do that is just so satisfying. This brings so much character development from Woody and opens the door to so many possibilities to tell knew and interesting stories for the toys. So overall was Toy Story 4 perfect? No, but it does do a lot of interesting things to not only keep you engaged but to also make you feel satisfied. 9/10

Watching this film, I couldn't help but be surprised at the positive response it has seemed to receive from critics and fans alike. It's a strange one to review because, had it been approached as a standalone project, I think it would've worked relatively well. As a successor to its preceeding - and close to perfect - trilogy... not as much - and not only because it fumbles over much of the same ground as 'Toy Story 2'.
Aside from the general atmosphere, which felt far less heartfelt, a lot of the toys' characters seemed conveniently changed to aid the plot. With some almost with completely different personalities, it was as though the whole gang (and the creators of the film) had forgotten everything they'd been through together prior to the events of this one. The bodacious Buzz and willful Woody we've grown to love seem now more subdued and melancholy: God knows that's what life can do to humans, but it didn't feel right for it to happen to them. On the whole, 'Toy Story 4' left me feeling less moved and more just... confused.
Things weren't all bad, though. Naturally, as a Pixar film, the animation is stunning; at times, almost life-like. It's fascinating to see how much they've come on since the original film, and how different the characters look today (hint - they've changed physically as much as they have mentally). Randy Newman, as usual, provides a beautiful score and, as much as I have roasted it, the plot is quite nice - if at times a bit samey. There's also an abundance of sweet, sentimental moments - and laughs, largely owing to new characters 'Forky' and the dynamic duo of 'Ducky' and 'Bunny'. Really, this wasn't an awul film; it's not its fault it failed to live up to the huge standards set by the three that came before it.

Fitting as a closure for Woody's story, Toy Story 4 is a beautiful movie that unfortunately falls behind due to the other installments of the franchise.

As I started reading the reviews for this movie i was shocked to see how many people liked it. The thing about Toy Story 3 is, it was a perfectly balanced happy/sad ending for the toys. And the thing about Toy Story 1-3 is that each of those movies have the toys we know and love (Woody, Buzz, Mr. Potato Head, Rex, etc.) all together in a family style adventure. Toy Story 4 might has well have been called 'Woody'. Excuse the double entendre. So let's call this movie what it is, a cash grab for Disney and Pixar to show how their animation has progressed over the last 20+ years. Pixar: 3 was enough, 4 is overkill.

I don't know if my imagination has just slowed down since I was a child but boy oh boy was this hectic. The film leaped from scene to scene in dizzying action montages and excellent animation quality that put the originals to shame. Whilst I prefer the simplicity and character rather than action-led plot of the first films, this latest installment was a huge step-up in inclusivity and nuanced humour that I think everyone will enjoy.

Toy Story 4 is a seamless addition to the franchise, introducing us to new and exciting characters. The new characters, especially Forky, add another level of humor and entertainment that even as an adult I can enjoy. The only thing keeping me from rating 5-stars in my disliking of the separation of characters. What made the previous movies stand out is that they kept the gang together. Instead, Woody separates from the gang and interacts with a bunch of new toys, and reunites with Bo Peep. While it's interesting to see his character on his own, the lack of incorporation of the other characters diminished the overall film. However, the storyline is strong, the comedy is solid, and the voice acting is stellar as always. This is a must-watch for both new and returning fans!

There is no love lost between myself and the Toy Story franchise. I find the entire concept to be ridiculous and kind of annoying. Between Woody’s constant whining, and the strange existential questions that these stories raise, I am never entertained and just feel emotionally manipulated. Yet even I, as a non-fan of the franchise, felt that the third film wrapped things up perfectly and there was zero need to delve into the world of Toy Story again. But Disney needed to create some new toys to sell, and keep this franchise at the forefront of consumer’s minds, so we are given Toy Story 4: The Search for More Money. This movie is everything I hate in the Toy Story films and none of the good stuff. It’s repeating so many of the same story beats from the previous films, and yet does it all with minimal appearance of the characters people have come to love from the other films. Instead we get a brief smattering of cameos from Andy’s toys and even Buzz is relegated to an annoying B-story while Woody is the only familiar character on center stage. Toy Story 4 opens up a cornucopia of new logical inconsistencies with this entire universe they’ve created, and makes no attempt to explain them. Let me just list some of the baseline logic problems that I struggled with while watching Toy Story 4: 1) Forky gaining sentience, 2) The fact that somehow he knows he is trash when the entire franchise is built on a film where a toy doesn’t realize he’s a toy, 3) The idea that a decorated spork could become a favorite cherished toy in less than 24 hours, 4) The idea that a 5-year-old girl would preserve that piece of trash for an entire year without stepping on it and busting it in half, 5) The wanton disregard for any “rules” that might have existed to conceal the fact that toys come to life, 6) And yet, the magical ability of all toys to know instantly when to go limp so they aren’t discovered walking around, 7) The idea of an underground society of discarded toys living on the fringe seeking to be played with by random kids in a playground. There’s plenty more, and by the end I was getting motion sickness from shaking my head so much. I suppose the intent is for me to look at Toy Story 4 with the eyes of a kid and experience the childlike wonder instead of getting bogged down in the minutiae. I might have tried that, however this is legitimately the first time I found myself completely bored with a film in this franchise. I didn’t know what to do with myself. They tried to simulate excitement as the plot was always moving, but it never felt like it was going anywhere. The humor in the film was flat and I never once laughed. Even with the myriad of new goofy characters, they didn’t strike a chord with me. I usually appreciate some of the humor in these movies, but the funniest characters in the franchise get maybe one line each. What was even more shocking was that Toy Story 4 did not get a single tear from me, I didn’t even well up thinking I might cry. That’s one thing that Pixar has mastered, and even in their lackluster efforts I find myself wiping away some tears. This one fell utterly flat. Toy Story 4 felt exactly like the cash grab I worried it was, and did nothing new or interesting (other than add more unanswerable questions about their universe, and create new toys to sell.) Needless to say, I was not a fan, this was the worst of the franchise in my opinion.

A masterpiece of film-making, story-telling and animation. Delightful and devastating in equal measure, it might well be the year's silliest and most soul-stirring film.
THE LOW-DOWN: 24 years ago, Pixar's Toy Story quite literally changed the face of animation as we know it. The film presented an entirely new way of telling a story, bringing characters to life via CGI - pixels over pencils, so to speak. At the same time, Toy Story set a new high standard for storytelling in film, proving conclusively that animated movies aren't just for kids. In the intervening decades, the franchise has even made a strong case in favour of sequels - demonstrating that they're not necessarily soulless cash-grabs. Toy Story 4 is very much a part of that grand tradition. This is smart, soulful, sublime film-making: somehow entertaining and profound all at once.

THE STORY: Sheriff Woody (voiced by Tom Hanks) is trying his best to adjust to life with Bonnie (Madeleine McGraw) - the little girl who inherited Andy's beloved childhood toys at the end of Toy Story 3. Even though he's forgotten more often than not, Woody remains intensely focused on Bonnie and her happiness. This means going into full babysitter/bodyguard mode when Bonnie creates Forky (Tony Hale), a spork with twists of wire for hands and clumsy wooden popsicle sticks for feet. As Woody tries to keep the trash-oriented Forky safe, he's swept into an accidental adventure - one in which he meets old friends and learns new truths about who he is and who he has yet to be.

THE GREAT: Perhaps the most remarkable thing about Toy Story 4 is the fact that it feels like the natural, necessary final chapter of a story told in four parts. There's no way that any of this could have been planned when Pixar first introduced us to Woody in 1995, but the progression in both narrative and character development feels utterly organic. Woody has spent the last three films grappling with his existential fear of being lost, forgotten or replaced, from his first meeting with the brash Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) to the day Andy outgrew him and went away to college. This film challenges Woody - and his audiences - to think hard about second chances, about changing how you look at yourself, about finding and embracing a new purpose in life. As such, Toy Story 4 might be the most philosophical movie you'll see this year, in the best possible way.

THE NOT-SO-GREAT: There actually isn't all that much to complain about. The plot machinations can feel a little clunky at times, but Stephany Folsom and Andrew Stanton weave so much joy and humour into their screenplay that the film still zips along. As this is very much Woody's movie, fan-favourite legacy characters like Buzz and Jessie (Joan Cusack) inevitably end up taking a back-seat. Even then, however, they each still get moments to shine. You might find yourself both thoroughly amused and mildly annoyed by the antics of Ducky (Keagan Michael-Key) and Bunny (Jordan Peele), a symbiotic pair of new characters who were clearly inserted into proceedings for comic relief.

FORKING FUNNY: Give it up for Forky, surely the best new animated character of the year. Voiced with a bewildered tenderness by Hale, Forky is a delight - a walking, talking identity crisis created out of one little girl's love and imagination. Even better? With his magnetic attraction to all nearby trash-cans, Forky is a fandom meme just waiting to happen. A close runner-up is daredevil stuntman Duke Caboom, who reportedly owes his ridiculously charming posing and personality to current internet darling Keanu Reeves' commitment to the role. Toy Story 4 even manages to make its main antagonist, Gabby Gabby (Christina Hendricks), both terrifying and endearing - although there are fewer shades of grey when it comes to her ventriloquist-doll minions, led by the determinedly creepy Benson.

COWBOY BLUES: Ultimately, Toy Story 4 belongs to Woody, and rightfully so. He is this franchise's Captain America, in more ways than one. This film pays loving tribute to Woody's big heart and unwavering, self-effacing loyalty, even as it shakes up his life and world-view when he encounters old friend and possible paramour Bo Peep (Annie Potts) again. (Bo, by the way, is now super-cool and as far away from a fragile damsel-in-distress as anyone can be.) Woody's decisions and revelations about himself will make you weep with the most complex and bittersweet of emotions. There is joy and sorrow here, hope and heartbreak, final farewells and new beginnings, often in the same moment. In other words, it's the stuff of life itself, and it's glorious.

CREDITS WHERE CREDITS ARE DUE: You'll definitely want to stay throughout the credits of the film, which are peppered with closing scenes that are essential to tying up the overarching narrative. At the very end, you'll even be rewarded with a happy ending for one of Toy Story 4's most minor of characters.

RECOMMENDED? In every possible way. Toy Story 4 is a masterpiece of film-making, story-telling and animation. Delightful and devastating in equal measure, it might well be the silliest and most soul-stirring film you'll see this year.

Toy Story 4, is an emotionally satisfying ending to a beloved character, the animation is still outstanding, and most of the jokes work. The new characters are cute, and fun to hangout with, and the opening scene can make you cry. The score/music is still very well done, and the voice acting is still good. Ventriloquist puppets are creepy enough by just sitting still, but what if they started chasing you? If you haven't watched the Toy Story series, it is basically about toys that come to life. There are stuffed animals, action figures, rag dolls, and yes, creepy ventriloquist puppets. I really thought Disney decided to make Toy Story 4 a horror sequel, but all they did was live by the motto "to infinity and beyond!" and prove that their creative universe knows no bounds.

Toy Story 4 follows the adventures of a group of toys led by a cowboy rag doll named Woody. These are the same characters from the previous movies, but now they have a new owner: a little girl named Bonnie. On her first day in kindergarten, Bonnie makes a new toy she calls Forky out of a spork and random materials from the trash. This simple creation is now the center of her life.

There is one problem: Forky only wants to stay in the trash, because...well, he technically is trash. However, Woody knows that this little spork is the most important thing in Bonnie's life. With the help of his friends, our protagonist tries his best to help Forky find his true purpose. 

That turns out to be a recurring theme throughout the movie. Like Forky, most of the new toy characters struggle to understand their true worth. Woody meets these new characters on a trip with Bonnie and her parents to the carnival. Remember the creepy ventriloquist puppets I mentioned? They are the sidekicks of the antagonist, Gabby Gabby, who is a defective doll that lives in the carnival's antique store. She has a false idea that fixing her voice box is the key to finding an owner, which is why she attempts to steal Woody's voice box. In the end, something happens that gives her more than just material completeness. If you plan to watch this movie, expect to see interesting and complex characters!

Overall, the plot is entertaining and dynamic, with bits of comedy, drama, and action. The lighting, atmosphere, and general cinematography are fascinating. Since I bought and watched this movie on YouTube, I couldn't resist the urge to pause the film and look at the toy material details and the realistic environment textures—even the spiderwebs and dust in the antique store. That is also a good idea if you want to spot Disney and Pixar easter eggs. If I could change one part of the story, it would probably be the setting, since carnivals and theme parks are a bit overused.

All in all, I highly recommend Toy Story 4. It amazes me to think that it was released in June 2019—almost 24 years after the first movie. The series is older than me, but I have watched and enjoyed all four movies, which is why I am giving it a 4.5 out of 5. The plot, animation, and music are great. The film score is heavy and exaggerated in a good way, especially for younger audiences. The whole experience leaves me wondering: will there be anything more after Toy Story 4?

And when Woody decided to go with Bopeep, ( sorry if I spelled her name incorrectly) wouldn't Bonnie, or her parents notice? I bet that eventually she would remember Woody, and want to play with him, then notice he's gone. Also, in the ending, when the duck and the rabbit, ( I forgot their names ) stayed with Woody and Bopeep, I realized I never saw them decide they don't want to go with a human. An unnecessary sequel without the charm of the original trilogy.

Josh Cooley's animated Pixar sequel Toy Story 4 (2019) falls short of its predecessors by far. It lacks the warm tone and endearing purpose of Toy Story, Toy Story 2, and Toy Story 3 that told the tale of beloved toys watching their child owner grow into a young man and be okay with that. Toy Story's narrative is over before Toy Story 4 even starts, so I was apprehensive about why Rashida Jones' story would make this movie necessary to continue Toy Story's plot. 

Well, it's not. Toy Story 4 has to manufacture backstory for the long forgotten character Bo Peep, who was largely ignored in 2 and 3 in lieu of Jessie, so that she can suddenly come back into Woody's love life. Andy is gone and all his toys belong to the adolescent Bonnie, who is relatable as a little girl afraid of school, desperate to find a friend. So, Bonnie makes one out of a spork so that Toy Story 4 can happen. Andrew Stanton, John Lasseter, and Josh Cooley's writing is basic with obnoxious modern humor and standard narrative choices with little experimentation or risks. All the charming aspects to Toy Story 4 come from the fact that I already care about these toys because of the previous Pixar pictures.

Josh Cooley's direction is fairly plain and lifeless as he takes you from moment to moment with little charm. The contemporary computer animation is as impressive and realistic as 3D computer graphics ever captivated me. I just wish Cooley had more style to his direction. Axel Geddes creates a slow pace with his lethargic editing. Toy Story 4 is only 100 minutes long, so why does it drag so much? Basic cuts and unfunny writing make scenes linger and jokes bomb. Jean-Claude Kalache and Patrick Lin's cinematography has some gorgeous choices with lights, shadows, and all the space the toys wander in, so at least the wide shots are neat. I most appreciate their gentle close-ups during all the touching scenes Woody shares with Bo Peep. Randy Newman's score is nice, but fairly understated as no songs stand out in Toy Story 4.

I will say that I do adore Bo Peep's cool redesign into a strong, independent, complex woman with her own agency to choose her life. Her romance with Woody was always a highlight of the Toy Story franchise, so bringing her back in style was a welcome choice to me. Annie Potts is magnificent as Bo Peep with her same sweet and alluring voice, but with a tenderness and confidence new to Bo Peep. She is by far the best aspect of Toy Story 4. I hope Annie Potts gets more roles like Toy Story 4. I wonder if we'll see Bo Peep again sometime?

I found Tom Hanks resplendent as the desperate Woody foolishly trying to save Forky all for Bonnie, only to have Bo Peep tell him he's wasting his time all for a little girl who will move on eventually. Hanks has been a steadfast pillar of emotional resonance with his affectionate and memorable voice acting as Woody throughout the Toy Story movies, so it is very cool that Hanks returned to give Woody a proper sendoff.

Tim Allen is solid as Buzz Lightyear, but he strangely gets little to do as Toy Story 4 is clearly Woody's farewell. I really enjoyed Christina Hendricks as Gabby Gabby. Sadly, Joan Cusack's delightful Jessie is almost entirely forgotten for this adventure. You can hear a plethora of nice cameos in small voice acting roles throughout Toy Story 4 if you are interested to listen in carefully.

Tony Hale is super annoying as the obnoxious new character Forky and I say this as someone that likes Hale normally. It sucks because Forky takes up a ton of screen time that could have been better delegated to old favorite cast members. Key and Peele are horribly out of place as Ducky and Bunny with awful characters. Madeleine McGraw is nice and believable as the little girl Bonnie. Keanu Reeves is pretty funny as Duke Caboom, but his vocal presence is almost too recognizable for me. He's a bit distracting. Ally Maki is terrible as Giggle McDimples as she detracts from all the poignant moments between Bo Peep and Woody with incessant commentary. I pretty much hated all the new characters from Toy Story 4.

In conclusion, Toy Story 4's finale with Woody making the tough choice to leave Bonnie and his friends so that he might finally rest and experience life by exploring the world with Bo Peep is a very optimistic and mature ending that I was not expecting. Woody got his happy ending, even if Toy Story 4 ends on a bittersweet note as he must say goodbye to all his friends. Pixar delivers a moving conclusion to the Toy Story universe, so I truly hope this is the last one. They are already stretching the material thin for a movie.

Our favorite Toys are back for a fourth adventure. After the ending of Toy Story 3, no one thought we would ever see a 4th film. Going into this movie had me wondering can Pixar work their magic for a fourth time? The answer is yes! somehow this movie manages to be even better then the last one. The adventure and laughs keep on coming. The ending to this movie may even be more heart tugging then the last movie. The character forky is the best welcome to the franchise since Bullseye and Jessie.

I don't understand the haters for this movie. To me, it's another home run in the TS franchise. For one thing, the animation is absolutely breathtaking. Seriously, this movie looks almost real. It's shocking when you compare the animation from TS1 and 4. It was also great seeing Bo Peep back, being more of an independent character and badass with great interactions with Woody. It retains the charm of the first 3 movies as well. We see so many toys who just want a kid and Gabby Gabby is a great example of this. She's an antagonist but an understandable one because all she wants is a kid. The best part of this movie is Woody and I love how this movie shows how far he has come since the first movie, a selfess toy who wants to make other kids happy even if he's not loved and I know people have an issue with Woody leaving the gang but it makes sense because Bo Peep showed him being a toy isn't just about staying in a closet waiting to be played. There's more to do like helping other toys so Woody is still doing good in the world and obviously there's many exciting and emotional moments like the climax. It's not quite as good as TS2 and 3 though. It's a shame all the toys other than Woody are sidelined, Buzz is dumbed down and the movie definitely drags at times. Thay stuff just prevents it from getting 4.5 stars but I still adore this movie. Thank you Pixar for this.

C'mon PIXAR, give the audience a break.  Wasn't Toy Story 3 emotionally draining enough?  Once more Woody, the cowboy doll, is drawing closer to that eventual reality that he is an old unwanted toy.  It's actually a bit depressing in the beginning.  Then comes along the semi-suicidal spork and the crazy adventure where toys are lost and regained and Woody discovers another valuable life lesson.  At the end of the trail, there is yet another happy rescue for the toys but what about Woody?  Is it time for Woody to ride off into another sunset with Buzz or follow the carnival with an old flame?  

Apart from the wacky antics, there are these bittersweet scenes designed to jerk the tears out of any normal feeling human.  I mean I held it in but... it's tough and I'm wondering why...they're TOYS.  That Disney magic...evil if not ridiculous. 

There is also the typical everyday setting made to look humorously macabre. This time it's the little antique shop of horrors. And let's not forget the cool new toy cameos.  Toy Story 3 had Michael Keaton as Ken and now we have Keanu as Duke Kaboom...and honestly that alone is worth the cost of a rental.  Yes, he Canada!

The number 4 makes me nervous. In film, the trilogy is the gold standard. You make three movies, and then hang up your hat. Toy Story did this better than most. How many film series can boast Rotten Tomatoes scores of 99-100% across all films? It was, in many ways, a perfect trilogy.

And then, Toy Story 4 was announced. And lo, there was much wailing and gnashing of teeth. They were gonna screw it up. Even if the movie is OK, it can't reach the heights of the first three. They cannot recapture the magic. Woe is us!

Turns out, the magic is basically still there.

The weaving of old and new here is done masterfully. Familiar characters, new characters, returning characters, it all just works. Toy Story has always added a batch of new toys with each film, and the originality and fun of each one shines through here. It does come a bit at the cost of old favourites like Jesse and Rex, but the film still feels familiar.

The plot still feels Toy Story-ish without resorting to cheap fan service. It probably resembles the first Toy Story the most, but elements of all three films are there. The characters are still consistent as ever, and there is a wonderful mix of slapstick humour and genuine moments. True to form, Pixar makes you want to cry at the end.

Is it absolute perfection? No, but it's pretty darn close. That being said, if Pixar tries to make another one of these, I will break into Pixar HQ and put cat hair in the water supply.
If this were toy story three, or a short film to just say where bo-peep was, this would be brilliant. But it is unnecessary, if a great film. But Sporky gets old quick. Good but unnecessary.

Toy Story isn't just one the best animated franchises ever, it's one of the best cinematic franchises ever. It's rare when a series can mature with its audience, much like the Harry Potter franchise, but Toy Story 4 does just that, by adeptly creating a plot about ambiguous motivations, complex relationships, and uncertain endings. Bravo.

The worst of the series, but don't let that deter you. While unnecessary, especially given the perfect and much preferred ending of Toy Story 3, this is a fun, emotional, spectacularly animated film that is definitely worth a watch. What it lacks in the usual Toy Story humour, it makes up for in heart. My only real issue is the amount of fan favourite characters left to not really do anything for just another Woody story. But still an entertaining chapter, if not as satisfying a conclusion.

I was really worried about watching this movie as I absolutely loved the trilogy and didn't know what could be added to the story. I was concerned initially as it seemed to repeat familiar themes but then it became all sorts of wonderful. Very moving at the end.

The Toy Story franchise is the best of Pixar, and this one is no different. It's a lot of fun, with new characters to enjoy (Forky!) and a few emotional moments. The ventriloquist dolls are truly creepy, and I can imagine some of the scenes in the antique store could be scary for little kids. I like the direction it took Woody's character, and if this is the last one, it's a good place to end it. If I had one minor quibble it's that there are almost too many characters. But it's a great movie for all ages.

There are some really great moments in it but I don't think it's a sum of its parts.  By that I mean not everything fits well together as there are multiple story lines with vastly different themes.  For starters Buzz is a completely different character in this one and his friendship with Woody is almost forgotten.  Woody goes against his character in this film at the end.  Bo Peep has been completely revamped which is fine and her relationship with Woody is odd.  It's like they forgot that these two used to be together (however that works for toys)  Forky is the new guy and while he is important to the main story, he gets all the development he gets after 20 minutes.  There some good heartfelt moments in this film especially around the 'villain' which by the way, the scope of her power isn't really thought out.  It's worth checking out but this is probably the weakest of the 4 Toy Story films.

Upon first viewing of the trailer, a critics first response could easily be, "why would they do this?" Particularly following Toy Story 3's high point in the series, in what could have been interpreted as a fitting finale. However, Toy Story 4 takes the low expectations of a third sequel to new heights, providing a worthy entry to the classic series. The animation is, as one would expect at this point, captivatingly beautiful, and some of the best the series has to offer. Without repeating plot lines of earlier installations, Toy Story 4 brings the laughs, excitement, and bittersweet drama we've come to identify the series with. New characters are spot on (Forky, Duke Kaboom) adding to an already packed cast without the feeling of being overstuffed. I'd call this one a "fitting finale" too, but come on, it's Disney, there's more money to be made, and there hasn't been a Toy Story tale yet that hasn't taken the animated film to the stratosphere. This one is no exception, it's excellent.

It's getting high ratings based on name only. It's not up to the standard of the first 3 and it didn't need to be made. Toy Story 3 was a fine ending. Most of the characters from the original 3 have no role in this one. It's just about Woody and a new marketing character named Forky. And there's not 90 minutes worth of plot here. It's more like a 20 minute short stretched out to feature length because Pixar knows they can just pump out anything with the name Toy Story on it and it will bring in the money. Toy Story ended with Toy Story 3. This one is irrelevant.

Toy Story 4 is an animated comedy film produced by Mark Nielsen and Jonas Rivera in 2019. This film features Tom hanks as Woody, Tim Allen as Buzz, Annie Potts as Bo Peep, and Tony Hale as Forky. With one Oscar, 47 other wins and 51 nominations, Toy Story 4 received a  97% from Rotten Tomatoes. I loved this comedy because it taught amazing life lessons while following a group of friends, old and new who worked to help each other.   

 

The story follows the toys' life after Andy leaves for college and gives his toys to Bonnie. When Bonnie starts kindergarten she makes a new toy out of a spork, named Forky. The friends embark on a road trip adventure and struggle to keep Forky out of trouble. When Forky wanders off into the open, Woody makes it his responsibility to return him safely back to Bonnie. On his journey to get back to Bonnie, Woody takes a slight detour and is unexpectedly reunited with an old friend from Andy's house.   

 

The movie starts in a sweet nostalgic way with the classic to the movie franchise, "You've got a friend in me" and shows Andy all grown up giving his toys to Bonnie, this scene ends showing Bonnies' name on Woodys' boot where Andys' used to be.  Woody struggles adjusting to the change at Bonnies'  no longer being played with. This causes Woody to fight for a purpose and the experiences he once had with Andy.  Woody realizes  Forky is Bonnie's favorite toy and tries to get him to adjust and appreciate being a toy.  When Forky tries to escape on the road trip, Woody goes after him in attempt to keep Bonnie happy. Woody tells Forky he should feel lucky to be the favorite toy, and Forky finally understands when he is told he's Bonnies "trash" and that he is warm and safe to her. I love how he makes this connection. Woody and Forky then head down the road as Woody explains life as a toy and tells stories about Andy.  

 

I love how the idea of self-conscious is introduced by Woody when he explains to Buzz what an 'inner voice" is. Buzz then literally uses his automated voice to help guide him to make decisions. Woody wanders into an antique shop in hopes to locate a long lost friend and meets an old doll named Gabby Gabby who's missing her voice box. Gabby and her  gang of ventriloquist dolls are determined to retrieve one and targets Woody for the job. Woody ultimately gives up his voice box to save Forky and grants Gabby the satisfaction and experience he once had having his own kid. Gabby wasn't chosen by the kid she had been expecting, but was unexpectedly placed with a kid who was meant for her. Woody crosses paths with Bo and is faced with life as he knows it as a toy with a child, or being a lost toy with his dear friend. When Woody gets Forky back to the RV he is torn with leaving Bo behind. Buzz says "She'll be okay, I mean Bonnie." and helps remind Woody to  listen to his inner voice.  

 

I recommend this movie, it has a great meaning and story line that both kids and adults can relate to. Toy story 4 teaches kids to use their self-conscious as a moral compass and guidance. It also showed sacrifice by Woody going after Forky and giving up his voice box to give another toy a chance. Another lesson shown in this film was reason for living or purpose. Woody struggled with adjusting and feeling fulfilled as a toy .Bo helped him explore a different side a broaden his horizons to something new.  

 Woody needed more in life and needed to move on from the past. Leaving the toys to go with Bo was a decisions that would give him purpose and make him happier.

Toy story 4 was .produced June 21st and it was directed by John Lasseter. It stars Tom Hanks, Tim Allen, and Keanu Reeves. The movie made huge references to the previous movies.  I really liked the nostalgic feel the movie gave you. They didn't spend too much effort in all scenes you could tell the work was equal in every scene. I liked the movie, I would most definitely suggest it to others to watch with children or by themselves. 

Toy story 4 is out and it did really good numbers. Children loved it, adults loved it, and there is  an abundance of reviews online cherishing it. So I most definitely would recommend checking in to it if your into those kind of things that I've listed.

Buzz and Woody) somehow became pushovers with no leadership skills whatsoever. They couldn't do any right and the only one's that did were female. This movie not only failed to meet my expectations, it obliterated them. I can, however, praise the film for it's absolutely stunning animation, which made for a dazzling cinematic visual. Though the animation was superb, the story felt cheap, forced, and essentially ruined the childhood of many a viewer. What can only be described as infuriating is the fact that the the third installment in the Toy Story series wrapped the tale up very neatly and in a heartfelt manor, which causes its painfully unnecessary revival to be all the more unpleasant. The story also felt dragged along in places and utterly unmemorable, creating a frustrating, money making outlet of bland entertainment on Disney's end.

When I saw this movie, I was worried that it wouldn't live up to the legacy of the first 3, especially since I felt that 3 wrapped up the franchise just fine, my fears were quickly put at ease however, as this film kept me laughing and smiling the whole way through. Toy Story 4 has the same heart and soul as the last 3 movies and is not afraid to take the franchise in some new directions, and bring some surprises to the table. The complaints I do have are minor, mainly dealing with plot points that I felt were a bit rushed or clunky at times, yet overall this film is definitely a feel good family movie, and one that does its job at wrapping up the series. I rate Toy Story 4 a solid 8/10

I've watched all the Toy Story movies but I never really got into them. I think that, without the rose tinted glasses, this movie isn't as good as everyone says it is. It's an okay movie but nothing special.

There were 4 or 5 bits that made me chuckle, there's some alright comedy in this, but the plot is more suitable for a TV-show than a whole movie. Especially a movie that comes after an already excellent conclusion -and my favourite Toy Story instalment- Toy Story 3.

More objectionable, the majority of characters annoyed me. Not all the time, but often. Bonnie is a realistic portrayal of a child; an ungrateful, whiny being that'll throw anything it cherished the day before to the side like trash. For literal trash. And then yell murder when that piece of trash goes missing. Every forking time. "Real" children are something I don't enjoy seeing in fiction. Why not use the fact it's fiction to write a less douchy child? Her treatment of Woody spits on the ending of Toy Story 3, but I guess this sequel needs to hammer it in our heads that Woody is obsolete, otherwise him leaving at the end would raise eyebrows. I found Sporky unbearable in the first half as well, and his existence is a missed opportunity to answer the question: how come he's alive? Bo Peep was sort of cool, but mostly came across as a bitch. I felt no chemistry between her and Woody. The carnival plushies were funny, but overstayed their welcome at times. As for the rest of Andy's old toys, they were hardly in the movie. I would've liked to see more Buzz Lightyear, at the very least. Also, maybe I remember it wrong because it's been forever, but.. didn't Buzz and that cowboy girl develop a crush on each other in the previous movie? I can't even recall them interacting in Toy Story 4. Anyway, long story less long, it was uninteresting, mostly unpleasant, would not watch again. And those antique store dummies were aids.

Toy Story 4 is an unnecessary but great sequel to one of the greatest trilogies of all time. It has loads of emotions, laughs and nice moments. It rounds off Woody's story nicely (even though it could have ended at Toy Story 3) and it answers some questions that were left unanswered by the first 3 films. Bunny and Ducky are hysterical and Keanu Reeves as Duke Kaboom is brilliant. However, most of the original characters are hardly used and Buzz is dummed down to a huge extent which brings the movie down for me.

We loved the first three (all five-star). This one felt a little too "made by committee" and episodic, chunking in ideas to keep the story going. And the speedy sequences (so many speedy sequences) run at such a breakneck pace that you can barely see what's happening. As always, character is one of the greatest strengths, and there are some wonderful new ones and endearing scenes for the familiar old ones. I LOVE that Bonnie's parents have some meat on their bones, like most of us. ;^)

I felt like the plot really connected to the 24-year saga of the Toy Story series. The beginning was very emotional, the climax and all was understanding, interesting, and at the same time, comical (thank Ducky & Bunny), and the ending was once again emotional, but as well, astonishing and a good call. Woody (as well as Bo Peep in her own experience ever since her departure) felt unused in his new lifestyle with Bonnie and there are plenty of other toys that hardly ever got the approximate playtime that he did throughout his years with Andy and meeting with Bonnie, and when he decided to help other toys who never had that chance, it felt like the greatest gift one (toy) can give to another (toy). What's interesting is that Woody also did that in the ending of Toy Story 3, where instead of having his friends sent off into the attic for their possible eternity, he sent them off, including himself, to a fun new life (aka a second chance) with Bonnie. The point is, the whole story really clicks and makes a lot of sense. If you haven't seen this film, do yourself a carnival-sized favor and watch this movie! It is not trash (pun intended).

PS: You might want to stick around in the mid-credits. If you have a sense of humor, Ducky and Bunny have you covered once again!

Unfortunately, I didn't get to see this movie in theaters. I just watched this movie for the first time on Disney+ a few days ago. And, I'm happy to say that I enjoyed the hell out of this movie. It is a hilarious and emotionally impactful film with A+ animation (it looks real, especially in the beginning) and I loved the new characters, especially Ducky and Bunny. I was one of the people who was worried about this movie, because Toy Story 3 was a perfect ending to the trilogy. But, this movie proves that you can continue pass a believed ending, and still be fantastic.

Highly enjoyable, almost more streamlined than 3 which was a more robust and complicated messy rich emotional film and 4 is rather more of a focussed and cleaner affair. It introduces some great new characters, and a couple of excellent locations, I for one would happily see Woody and Bo running the antique store that functioned as a sort of ganger film-lite. Bo Peep, excised from the last films, comes back with aplomb, a perfect foil for Woody and his arc, a brilliant character, and Woody has a brilliant arc in this film, a film dealing with the next steps of parenthood, after saying goodbye in 3, it's now about finding new purpose in later life. Not very often it's very funny, but it's quality over quantity, inbetween the laughs is a family drama with characters we've been living with for some time, it's like hugging a distant cousin that you forget you love so much until you see them again.

The most consistently great film franchise in history does it again. Stunning next level animation makes some shots look borderline real without messing with aesthetic if the reality. And once again the emotional beats and meaningful through-line creates an experience that definitely competes in my mind for the top spot in this franchise.

Another 'Toy Story's could just have been very excruciating- the very thought is. But the film is so not-silly, well crafted and so animated in its very storytelling that the extension works. The film is a full-blown original despite having three prequels. It's linearity is no problem and the film is a savage end off which will leave you choked with emotion and happy at heart as you meet the old friends yet again and go for an interestingly menacing journey with new ones. The film, in short is a delightful joyride, and just unmissable cinema. Heartwarming, light, breezy and delightful- it's very ideas make it worth your time and money.

Pretty much a perfect saga here.  My only real issues with Toy Story 4 are that it could have been funnier, a lot of the other characters are sidelined for Woody and Bo's story, and how it's ultimately kind of unnecessary.  But even these issues I can kind of justify.  It's more about the emotions than the comedy, the story really is Woody's story, and despite being unnecessary it does take the Toy Story story into a new direction.  It visits a lot of familiar territory, but does so in some new ways.  The villain for example does not have your standard Toy Story villain ending, and without diving too deep into spoilers it's kind of a tearjerker.  And yes the whole thing is a tearjerker.  The return of Bo Peep I found an interesting choice, but she wasn't the most dynamic character in the first two films.  Here, they expand on her a lot while still keeping the essence of her character, and she becomes on of the most interesting characters in this whole franchise through her arc.  And yeah that ending, it broke me, honestly I was holding it together fine but there is a line from Buzz that comes at the end that if you're not crying yet, you will.  Toy Story 4 doesn't quite feel as polished as some other Pixar films, but it's still an incredibly solid film with characters we love and some new ones that are a lot of fun.  I haven't even talked about Forky, he's a spectacular new entry.  It's not a part of the story I wanted, but now that it's here I'm glad I got it.  It's got all the heart and beauty and enough of the comedy to be a worthy entry in this franchise.

The worst Toy Story movie to date.
I don't know how to feel, maybe this movie just wasn't for me. I mean, I am a 22 year old man at this point but that shouldn't really matter.
The previous movies have character and a plot that makes sense. This movie was just all over the place. We can start with the pacing, it was all over the place. The movie went from a slow moving plot to a montage in moments. It didn't feel coherent at all.
The characters that we have gotten to know through three whole movies where no where to be seen. I mean we barely got any time with Buzz Lightyear or Jessie or any of the rest of the gang.
Instead we got a story about Woody still being sour about not being the favorite toy anymore (the plot of the first Toy Story anyone?) and how he finds his purpose in getting his kid to be happy behind the scenes.
And the ending, I mean in what world would Woody leave the gang after 20+ years together just to be with one other toy? The whole plot of the other movies are that what matters most is friendship and being loyal? What happened to that.
Nonsensical plot, weird pacing and most of all it destroyed the great story that the three previous movies had built up over the course of two decades.

Woody and Buzz are off an another adventure with Bonnie, and her new friend Forky. Forky is such a funny and lovable character, and his existential crisis is a very relatable feeling. It was disappointing and worst of all forgettable. The plot felt very unpolished compared to Pixar's previous ventures with this franchise and it focused on introducing too many new characters that we had barely any screen time with any of the characters we actually care about. Woody didn't even really feel like Woody in this entry almost like Hanks had stopped caring about the role and/or was given a kind of lousy script. One of the most heartbreaking parts of this entry is that the relationships we really developed in the first two entries were forgotten about. Buzz and Woody had one scene of development together, that's it. I also feel like Buzz got the short end of the stick as far as I feel like they could have written him out of the script and nothing would have been lost as far as the plot is concerned. Jessie (never been my favorite character) also got maybe 2-3 minutes of actual screen time and a sentence or two of script. I can't even remember Bullseye being in the movie. Bonnie's new toys didn't get enough time to actually have much of a personality, the Key and Peele toys weren't that funny (suprisingly) and just cheapened the overall experience. Bo Peep was an annoying character for me. I am all for equality between genders but this just seems so tacked on and politically charged and irked me just like Belle in the live action's Beauty and the Beast or those Frozen girls. She was annoying to watch and had the same personality as every other Disney princess since Disney "woke." The movie's only antagonist's story arch resolved with 20 minutes to go and she was utterly forgettable. Her dummy henchmen are going to be giving my boys nightmares for the rest of their lives and were definitely not something I expected to see in a family movie (and I'm not one to shelter my children from potentially scary scenes, looking at you shark attack in Finding Nemo). I'm surprised how high this has been rated and just don't see it. For me it ranks right around Monster's University on the Pixar lineup with Cars 2 (never saw 3) being one of the few below it. I even liked Finding Dory significantly more than this one and that was the movie that made me realize that Pixar has lost it's magic. If it weren't for Inside Out I probably wouldn't bother seeing any more of Pixar (or Disney for that matter) until they make some big changes.

This was the first Toy Story that left me with a humdrum feeling inside. I knew the underlying lesson was rich, the animation gorgeous and the story was full of excitement/adventure. It’s just...the franchise has become tiresome.

Toy Story 4 seems like the type of movie that just shouldn't have worked out. The third film is loved by virtually everyone and the fourth film overrides the ending of the last movie. So, why is Toy Story 4 much better than it should've been? Well, before we get to that, let's discuss the obvious problems: Bonnie and the lack of development of old characters. The former has been the butt of jokes on the Internet thanks to her visible neglect of Woody. While this does cheapen the impact of the ending of the last movie, she's still only a 5-year-old girl and neglecting that one toy is normal behaviour for children her age. So calm down, guys. And with regards as to why the toys spend most of the movie literally and metaphorically in the back seat, I think the shorts and TV specials did help the characters go through arcs. That is, if those are even canon anyway. And they weren't completely useless nor were they interchangeable. Now that I've played the devil's advocate to the two things people have complained about, let's get down to talking about why this movie is good. The animation (uh-doy!). At times, you'd swear Pixar was just showing off, especially compared to how outdated the '90s movies look (mostly the first film, but the second film has its more awkward moments despite having much better human designs and outside scenes). And the script still has its share of emotional and comedic moments, helped by the voice acting. And I do like the new characters and am glad to see how Woody has come a long way from being the guy who'd resort to pushing Buzz under a table, out of Andy's line of sight, just so that he can get to go to Pizza Planet. I do find the ending a worthy end to Woody's story, especially considering the override. Still less esoteric than the one from Wreck-it Ralph 2, if you ask me. I enjoyed Toy Story 4 and consider it a worthy, and presumable ACTUAL, conclusion to not just the series but Pixar's "sequel phase" given that they have no sequels planned for the next decade...at the time I'm writing this review anyway. I just hope that they'll be able to handle the responsibility of making 2 original movies in 2020 without John Lasseter. Though Soul does have Pete Docter directing it, so I wouldn't be too concerned. Only time will tell if they'll gain "Inside Out" levels of acclaim.

Woody is back and about to go on a road trip with his new owner Bonnie and her new favourite toy ‘Forky' a toy she made herself on her first day at nursery.
Woody takes it upon himself to play ‘Dad' to Forky who considers himself to be nothing but trash and throws himself in a bin at every opportunity.  When Forky escapes Woody goes after him and is re-united with Bo-Peep as well as having to watch out for a pull-string doll named Gaby Gaby who wants his voice box as hers is broken. 
The ensuing adventure is just as much fun as the previous Toy Story films and is laden with comedy, classic film references and wonderful animation.
As well as making audiences laugh, Pixar are masters at pulling heart strings,with some very emotional moments and the ending is particularly bittersweet. Toy Story 4 is a wonderful ending to the exceptionally brilliant Toy Story saga.

I want to start this off by saying that I am a huge Pixar fanboy but I was skeptical about the notion of making another Toy Story after the way Toy Story 3 left the series. Plus adding on to another already stellar trilogy is cause for concern. Now, sitting here writing this, I believe this is my favorite out of the four. The animation is the best in Pixar's relatively short history and the writing is almost as good. For some reason they left buzz on the back burner. Woody once again is sent through a life changing struggle that ultimately ends in a way I felt Toy Story 3 could have gone. However, the best character of the entire film is Forky, an innocent but thought provoking spork that just wanted to be trash. Once again, Pixar perfected what Disney was could not to do (looking at you olaf).

The Joker is a 2019 Drama/Thriller featuring the talents of Joaquin Phoenix and co. I personally really enjoyed this movie. From the amazing cinematography to the Oscar-worthy Score, this movie is one of the best to come out this year. Joaquin Phoenix's performance is one of the most mesmerizing performances I've ever seen on screen, the way he depicts his character is not realistic, but also deeply dark and disturbing to viewers. This man is able to creep out and disturb the audience just by laughing. No music or special effects needed. The plot, though flawed and at times unrealistic, is very, very dark and disturbing. I wouldn't recommend this movie to young audiences. To everyone else, though, this is a must-watch to not only become aware of many difficulties of the mentally ill, as well as why horrible things like what happens in this movie happens in real life.

At this point everyone knows what Pixar is… THE ANIMATION GOAT. They have been just putting out banger after banger for years and they do not seem to be stopping any time soon.

Toy Story however has always been their most prized franchise. It is the film that started it all, and it is easily the most popular franchise of any that Pixar has put out. To be honest 3 is so perfect and heartwarming that it felt like the perfect end of the franchise. When people heard this was happening, and saw the first trailer, there was many reservations heading into this.

Never in doubt though Pixar still brings the heat, especially with the Toys. This story is about how the toys new owner Bonnie makes a new friend Forky, and he decides to get lost in the forest. Woody goes after him because he is just so noble, and winds up on the adventure of a lifetime. Any more and I would kinda be spoiling so lets just get to the grades and we will finalize another fantastic entrant to the Pixar canon.

Animation – A It is Pixar and they always do it right. There were some legitimately incredible shots that could have been in live action movies, particularly one where Woody and Forky are walking down a highway. They also managed to make a spork look normal and fit into the universe which is an achievement in itself.

Voice Cast – A+ All the big dogs are back, Hanks, Allen, Cusack, Ratzenberger, and all the old pals. However, we get four all time performances from new characters: Key and Peele as two bears that kids try to win at the carnival, Ally Maki as a toy cop, and Keanu Reeves (in the midst of a Keanuassaince) dominating the screen as a toy daredevil. It really does not get better than this as far as voices.

Music – B The score was typically very good, and they brought back You've Got a Friend in Me, but nothing really too crazy to put this over the edge for me.

Story – A This is where the worry came in for the Pixar heads, because the first three were so satisfying we did not want them ruined. This felt very natural though and did not have to retread anything from the past. It gave us a true ending to Woody's journey and at the end of the day this was always his story. I loved how they brought back Bo Peep, and the arc of the villain Gabby Gabby as well. As always Pixar comes through when they need to.

*A couple other tidbits

- Bonnie kind of stinks compared to Andy, There I said it.

- Jeff Garlin had like two amazing moments in this as well which always puts a smile on my face.

We may have been a tad worried going in, but as always Pixar knocked this one out of the park. Another incredible story about the Toys and another notch in their unrivaled filmography.

This movie was crafted exceptionally well, we join our old friends Woody, Buzz, Bo Peep, and all the others... Including Mr Potato Head, still voiced by Don Rickles, two years after his death. 25 years after the original films release, this film still has the ability to captivate audiences of all ages. We find our selves, once again following woody on an adventure, that spirals in to a chaotic turn of events. As we have come to expect from the franchise. The script is very well written with a lot of first time comedic value. Especially the dialogue between Woody, and his newly found friend Forky. A talking spork. You can also expect some moments of great sadness, as this seems to be the last time all of our friends will be together. With all that said this movie will stand the test of time, and is definitely worth a watch, or 2, or 3, or 4.

People didn't want a toy story 4 as it would ruined the way that toy story 3 ended, but it didn't at all. This isn't a "Andy" film, this one is focusing on Bonnie growing up with the toys and also showing us that Woody needs to move on from being Andy's favourite toy. Yes this film moves away from focusing on the main set of toys to focus on the brand new set of characters, but that's where the humour comes from and this is definitely the funniest toy story movie and its down to the new characters, the main stand out is Forky, the chemistry with him and Woody is 2 stand out performances inside this film. The main villain, Gabby Gabby is probably the most complex villain in the franchise, but I don't think she is the greatest villain, but still great to watch. Bringing back Bo Peep into the fold really helps to bring Woody's arc to a wonderful and emotional ending. However I do not think this is the most emotional toy story film as that belongs to toy story 3, but it's still emotional to see what happens at the end of the film, especially the final words that Woody and Buzz share together. That door has closed, or has it?????

Toy Story 3 wrapped up on a seemingly conclusive note. That all changed when Toy Story 4 was announced. Upon learning of a fourth sequel, I was unsurprised and disappointed at Disney's seemingly endless level of corporate greed.

Cynicism aside, I was pleasantly surprised (to an extent). Toy Story 4 manages to retain the charm and whimsy of the earlier films and isn't a total soulless cash-grab. I actually liked the themes it explored as well as the new characters - Forky's existential crises and Key/Peele's arguing were both quite enjoyable. This was a good, not amazing, Toy Story film that is likely to leave fans of the franchise or just fans of Pixar in general pleased.

SPOILERS:
If I was a feminist I would've loved this movie. Unfortunately I still haven't quite been swayed by the latest feminist agenda popping up in movies and TV in recent years. Toy Story 4 tried hard and there was plenty of good moments and narrative absent of any agenda that made the film enjoyable. But the feminist moments just left a bad taste in my mouth. Woody is demeaned to the point of an "accessory" by Bo Peep, and yet we're expected to believe that Woody would love Bo Peep and just leave all his old friends behind who he's been with for all the three previous movies. It almost encourages masochism and low self esteem. It just feels spiteful and wrong. And then the passing of the sheriff's badge from Woody to Jessie just felt like a nod to the passing of the patriarchy to the matriarchy, which, again, if I were a feminist I'd have loved that moment. But to me it feels forced and politically motivated and I prefer art to be honest and reflect reality, rather than try to force fit an agenda onto a narrative in the hopes of recreating reality. It basically turns art into propaganda. But besides those moments, the rest of the movie was pretty good.

There is this very irritating feeling when you watch a movie that everyone praised to infinity and beyond, and then you realize that you are among the very few that found it to be not great at all. Toy Story 4 is one such movie for me. Yes, some conversations are pretty good, the photorealistic animation is great and the film has its fine moments for sure, but overall the script is just rehashed in dialogue and themes from all of the previous movies. It's a very lazy, very unnecessary movie given the greatness of ‘Toy Story 3' and its finale. The humor is fine, but rare, and its action/adventure elements are overwhelming and very uninteresting. And I love Pixar to death, but this particular franchise is the most overrated thing they've ever produced, and this film specifically is their worst after ‘Cars 2'. That's why I find it very frustrating when critics show bias toward a certain franchise and heap praise when in reality this is just a weak movie when watched with objective, unbiased eyes.

Woody and the gang embark on one last adventure in Toy Story 4.  While on a road trip with her parents Bonnie losses her new favorite toy that she made in preschool and Woody attempts to get him back, and along the way he reunites with Bo Peep, who's joined a traveling carnival.  Most of the original cast returns along with several new additions, including Christina Hendricks, Tony Hale, and Keanu Reeves.  Once again the series takes on some very poignant themes, but it isn't quite as nuanced as in previous films and comes off as kind of talky and heavy handed.  The lack of a strong villain is also problematic.  However, the comedy is incredibly well-done and delivers a lot of laughs.  But it also has a lot of heart.  Though it's not as strong as some of the other entries in the franchise, Toy Story 4 is a fun and heartwarming family film.

I'm a massive Toy Story and Pixar fan since 1995. Toy Story changed how I thought, it's THAT kind of movie for me. And I'd be here all day talking about what I love about Toy Story 1, 2 and I'd be here for a week talking about what I love about Toy Story 3 which is a true masterpiece.

It's not a bad movie just... it didn't do much for me.

I'll tell you one thing that bugged me when it was over was I could count on one hand the number of times I laughed. Where the hell were the jokes in this movie? That bit where the bunny and the chick hatch their plan... get it... but where they go over how they're gonna steal the antique shop owner's key... is one of the funniest gags in ANY Pixar movie. That was the first laugh for me and it was maybe 50 minutes into the movie. That's not the kind of joke/laugh ratio I like.

Forky... lemme talk about Forky....... Forky sucks ass.

When I saw that character in the trailer I had a feeling that character would be annoying. And he's not annoying it's just... they don't do ANYTHING interesting with him at all. This idea of NEW LIFE and they don't do anything cool with it. It's Frankenstein's monster! The number of directions you can do with the creation of a toy and how they begin life seems infinite and... it felt like they threw all of that away. What a letdown. And they spend the first 20 minutes of the movie with his character, too which sucks.

It's a decent story, in these movies they've managed to do a great job giving us these takes on life for toys. For some toys it's about being owned and loved by a kid and the idea of being lost or abandoned is a hell without end....... unless you're Bo evidently.

Bo is a whole new and great character, living this almost Mad Max in the wasteland existence driving around in a skunk car.... long story that's never explained. And I don't wanna give away where the story goes but they make that an option for some of our characters and it's an interesting place to take the story..... but I've seen WAY more interesting stuff happen in these movies.

I think the biggest problem this movie has is Toy Story 3.

Toy Story 3 had everything, a great and HARROWING story, laugh out loud moments every other minute, fantastic new characters, a STELLAR villain in Lotso Huggin' Bear and a climax I don't think Pixar will ever top, frankly.

Not to mention the best opening scene in a Pixar movie with this sort of fantasy that I read as what literally happens for toys when they're played with, they're transported to this other reality where anything is possible. It made Woody's desire to be with Andy make even MORE sense. Who wouldn't want to be a part of adventures like that.

So I was pretty bummed when Toy Story 4 by the time it was over had nothing in common in Toy Story 3. There IS no villain, no Sid, no Stinky Pete, no Lotso, no life or death stakes.... and wow is that a nice way to make me care less about what happens in an adventure story.

And the ending was.... so underwhelming to me. Like infuriatingly underwhelming.

After the pitch perfect The End closure in Toy Story 3, they give us a NEW ending that was so left field and lame to me and sent me out of the theater with a bad taste in my mouth.

And also as a fan of these movies I was crushed that the characters I grew to love like Jessie, Bullseye, Hamm, Potato Head, Rex... aside from Woody, Buzz and Bo the characters I knew were relegated to almost cameos in their own movie. It's like watching an X-Men movie and the only characters that get scenes are Wolverine, Xavier and Jean Grey..... don't gimme all these new characters when we're not done with the old ones yet!

It's not the kind of sequel I hate where it makes the other films worse but based on its own merits... aside from Woody and Bo's story and the quality of the animation this movie did nothing for me.

Never mind the Toy Story movies, after incredible works of art like Inside Out and Coco coming out of Pixar this movie just seemed cookie cutter to me.

When I first heard they were making a Toy Story 4, I didn't think it was necessary at all. Toy Story 3 ended the story perfectly, what more could be done with it? Not to mention that it's a Pixar sequel made in the 2010s, which don't exactly have a great reputation. Toy Story 3 was great, Cars 2 was bad, Monsters University was okay, Finding Dory was good but forgettable (no pun intended), Cars 3 was okay and Incredibles 2 was a lot of fun but not as memorable as the first movie. It didn't help that none of the Toy Story 4 trailers impressed me. I walked into this movie cautiously optimistic. I hoped it would be at least as good as Incredibles 2 but I was ready for the possibility of a disappointment. However, after seeing the movie, I can confidently say that they did it again. They made another great Toy Story movie. It has an engaging and emotional story, a lovable and memorable cast of characters, interesting themes and ideas, the most beautiful animation that Pixar has put to screen yet, pitch-perfect voice acting, and really great action and comedy! While Toy Story 3 was the perfect ending, I think Toy Story 4 is a great epilogue. This is probably where the story would go next, whether you like it or not. I do have some criticisms though. Some of the writing and comedic timing felt surprisingly clunky and off a couple of times and the ending does feel a little rushed. The ending of Toy Story 3 was definitely a better finale to the series as a whole, it was more epic and larger in scale, but this is more of a finale to the arcs of the main characters. I can't think of a more fitting way to end both this story and the 2010s decade of Pixar movies. It came in with a Toy Story movie and it went out with a Toy Story movie, and it looks like this is the last Pixar sequel we're going to see for a long time. It's been confirmed that there are no sequels coming out for the foreseeable future and they will be putting their focus on original films only. That sounds good to me! Overall, this is a must-see for any fan of the Toy Story movies. It just might be another instant classic. Highly recommended.

It wasn't a bad movie. It wasn't. I think if it was something I hadn't grown up with and had Pixar not hyped it up and made it, I would have liked it more. But there just wasn't enough EMOTION. (Franchise spoilers) The first Toy Story, there was that moment when Woody told Buzz he was jealous of him and felt it should have been him strapped to a rocket. The second one had the sadness of Jessie's abandonment. The third one...oh the third one made me cry. But this one? There wasn't enough to make me FEEL. Buzz has a pretty idiotic side plot, Jessie and Andy's original toys are almost never on screen, and Woody and Bo just didn't build it up enough. I kept sitting in the theater and waiting to feel like I was experiencing this film, waiting for Pixar to hit me in the heart, and it didn't happen. Towards the end there was a part where I think I was supposed to cry and I just didn't. It wasn't built up enough. The third one was much better. This is the weakest one in the franchise. Not a horrible movie, but just not up to the standard these movies and Pixar have set.
