Heartfelt, funny and gorgeously animated, "Toy Story 4" is a thrilling final chapter in the beloved animated series. Packed with plenty of colourful characters, hilarious laughs and terrific performances from an A-list cast, the film delivers everything that fans could have hoped for. At a first glance, extending the series may have seemed like an impossible feat. However, director Josh Cooley has pulled it off seamlessly. Not only does "Toy Story 4" bring back the beloved toys we've grown to adore, but it also introduces fresh faces into the cast. Forky, for instance, is the funniest character and a standout in the new additions to the cast. Although "Toy Story 4" offers fun family entertainment, it is not a film without flaws. At times, it feels slightly rushed and doesn't give all the characters a chance to shine. Due to its rushed pacing, it isn't quite on par with its predecessors in terms of quality. Nevertheless, fans of the franchise will definitely enjoy "Toy Story 4" and so will movie-goers seeking family-friendly entertainment this summer season. If this truly is the last time we see Woody and his friends on the big-screen, its a fitting farewell to the toys we've grown to love and adore.
What else can I say, the end crowns the work. It was marvelous journey to the childhood, that I won't forget for long.

We all thought exactly the same thing when Pixar announced they were going to makeToy Story 4, What?! The third film ended the series perfectly. However after seeing Toy Story 4 I have to say I am very impressed and surprised. I really liked this film. It is definitely the weakest of the Quadrilogy for me, however that doesn't say all that much as all the movies are so good. Pixar have done it again. They have put in so much care, effort and time into this. It's been 9 years since the 3rd film so there was a lot of expectation. This is a funny, moving, charming film which is a great extension of Toy Story 3's ending assuming this is the last one. The ending is satisfying, it's not super dark and intense like the incinerator from part 3 but it leaves you feeling warm. The new characters are all awesome, especially Gabby Gabby. Her character arc was very emotional, we think at first she is the antagonist however that is since revealed not to be true. I also think Duke Caboom, Ducky and Bunny are all hilarious.This is also a greta ending for Woody and I feel like Woody's character has really come full circle and has matured. Its great seeing Bo back and rekindling her relationship with Woody and seeing how her character has changed. The music is classic Toy Story and it works. It moves at a great pace. Its a wonderfully surprising return to these characters but the only criticism I have is that a lot of the original characters don't get a lot to do, which is a slight shame but other than that, well done Pixar! :) This movie was unnecessary but I am glad you made it. But now is a good place to stop. The Toy Story films have been consistently fantastic and the 4 movies work and I really feel this film is the official ending of the Toy Story saga and it should stay that way. I would score this film a 9/10
Simply mazing.. definitely has to be the last one based on the end.

At my daughter's request we saw this in the theater the day after her seventh birthday.   There are some really interesting parts to it – the Forky the spork, for example, who doesn't want to be a toy and has a "death drive" of throwing himself into the trash; and conversely, the doll Gabby, who feels she can only be a complete toy with a working voicebox, and is willing to hurt others (in particular, Woody) to acquire one.  Toy Story 4 probably features the least interaction with humans, and specifically families, of the entire series, a gap which is partly filled by Woody, who tries to parent Forky, and Bo Peep, who looks after her sheep and other "independent" toys.  And in the end, both choose a life together, away from humans, after helping Gabby find a girl for her.  Is this what it looks like when toys grow up themselves, or is it more like retirement?   While neither kiddo is especially into dolls or action figures, this series still retains its charm for them, I think because it captures the mystery of childhood play.  And that can sometimes be violent and unjust, as demonstrated by this film.
Toy Story 4's animation is breathtaking, but its real achievement comes in its well-developed characters and willingness to try out new characters.

Toy Story 4 is a generally enjoyable film, made better by the incredible animation that Pixar delivers. The lighting and shadows darting across Bo-Peep's facial features are a level of detail that can easily be taken for granted and it is fun to watch just to appreciate the spectacle and feat of CGI. 

That said, though, it was a little questionable at first as to whether this film was needed. Nobody was really asking for Toy Story number 4 . When the news was announced that Disney and Pixar were doing it I remember wondering why, what story was left to tell? We had concluded the tale, Toy Story 3 was a beautiful end to an animated saga that had carried a generation through childhood into adolescence, and now they were creating a fourth? Could we, as an audience that had departed this train and exited the platform be bothered to get back on board? I mean, where was it even headed? We all know how this goes, Disney did it with Pirates of the Caribbean, a new trilogy of films that can't live up to the originals and succeed only in tainting the franchise.

I was pleasantly surprised though to find myself exiting the cinema, having watched the most recent installment, with a sense of closure that I didn't even realise I needed.

I mean think about it this way. The end of Toy Story 3 left Woody nodding a solemn farewell to Andy, about to jump into a new life with Bonnie, the adorable and excitable kindergartener who could help these toys continue fulfilling their purpose as children's playthings. It was a bittersweet end, we connected with Andy as he clung on desperately to the remnants of childhood, but were happy to see another child find joy in playing with the characters that we'd grown to love through 3 incredible movies. 

But nobody was asking, yet probably should have been, what happens in 6 or 7 years time when Bonnie is too old to play with these toys? Are we going to have to pick up the story again and watch them all find a new home? And what about Bo-Peep? Where the heck is she? And what even defines a toy? Why are other seemingly inanimate objects in this franchise not sentient, and what happens if something that was not previously labelled a toy is suddenly redefined as one by a child playing with it?  

Toy Story 4, often horrifyingly, addresses all of these unanswered questions, and delivers a hilarious, emotional punch that nobody knew they needed. We are introduced to Forky, an agonised creation made from trash that suffers an existential crisis of identity whilst being, literally, talked down from the ledge by Woody. Somehow Disney turn this into a storyline that lasts 100 minutes, and though it felt more like the tying of several ends that I wasn't aware were even loose until they were picked up in this movie, it was nonetheless enjoyable to watch and entertaining throughout. Let us not forget, this is a kids film, and the giggles and laughter echoing through the screening are testament to the fact that this delivers to it's target audience. 

Will Toy Story 5 happen? Knowing Disney - yes. Should it? Probably not.

The movie was great, although, I agree, it wasn't needed. Even though the last movie In the franchise wrapped things up perfectly, with Woody and the rest of Andy's toys now belonging to Bonnie, it was nice to see what happened to the toys after the last film. The movie opens up with a flashback to nine years ago, back at Andy's house, where Woody and Bo Peep are being separated as Bo Peep gets sent away due to Molly (Andy's sister) going to college. We then cut back to present day where Bonnie starts her first day at kindergarten and she creates a new toy out of a plastic spork and some crafting materials, which she names her new toy "Forky". Forky, who Bonnie takes home, does not believe he is a toy and insists he is "trash". It is then that Bonnie and her parents go on a road trip, and Bonnie brings along her toys, including "Forky". Forky, still believing he is trash, jumps out of a window and Woody goes to find him. Woody then finds Forky and convinces him he is a toy (or, at least, "Bonnie's 'trash'".) Woody and Forky then join back up with the rest of the toys, but not before stumbling upon an old antique store, which Woody thinks Bo Peep is inside. Woody, and, by extension, Forky, then go inside to try and find Bo Peep, but do not find her. Instead, they find a new character named "Gabby Gabby" who says she knows Bo Peep and offers to take them to her. It is then that "Gabby Gabby" plans to take Woody's "voice box" as hers is defective. Woody then bolts out of there, but not before Forky is captured. Woody then wants to head back in and save Forky, knowing that Bonnie needs him, but ends up finding Bo Peep, who is roaming on her own. Woody then tells Bo Peep that he needs to get Forky back from the antique store, where he's being held captive there, but Bo initially refuses, saying she used to be there but was tired of "sitting on a shelf", not being bought by someone. They, eventually, end up going to save him. We then cut back to the other toys, who are in the RV, and Buzz is getting worried about Woody for being gone too long. He ends up trying to find him, but gets mistaken for a carnival toy. He tries to break free, but not before meeting two more stuffed carnival toys, being "Bunny" and "Ducky", who hate him for taking "top prize" at the carnival game. He then breaks free and sets off to find Woody, with "Bunny" and "Ducky" following behind, as they aren't done giving him "a piece of their mind". Buzz eventually finds Woody, and, by extension, Bo Peep, with "Bunny" and "Ducky" catching up to Buzz and beating him up. Woody then promises them he can take them to Bonnie to be played with (spoiler alert: he never does) and they get excited. The team then go out to find Forky, who they do eventually find, but not before Gabby Gabby tries to take Woody's "voice box". Woody, begrudgingly, lets her have it if it meant Forky would be set free, and she agrees. Gabby Gabby, with her "voice box" fixed, then tries to get a kid to take her home, but, ultimately, gets rejected. Woody then offers to take Gabby Gabby to Bonnie to be played with (which, again, he doesn't do.) Instead, Gabby Gabby sees a lost kid at the carnival and, knowing how she's a "lost toy", decides to cheer her up by being taken home by her. Woody then finally meets up with the rest of the toys, Bo Peep and Forky with him, but then decides to stay with Bo Peep as he wants to help other toys get played with. I really am not a fan of this ending. Yes, Woody found his "true calling", but he, not to mention "Bo" and the other new toys he met along the way, could have easily stayed with Bonnie to be played with, but, I guess "Pixar" just wanted another "feel-good" ending. Speaking of which, before the movie came out, I initially heard it was gonna be darker and more "heart-wrenching" than the last movie, so I went in to this movie expecting a "tear-jerker" similar to the "incinerator" scene from the last film, but I didn't get that. Yes, it was "warm-and-fuzzy", but it didn't "move" me. Maybe this is because I'm getting used to these kinds of movies. Overall, the film was good and I highly recommend you check it out.

This movie is a solid addition to the franchise. Pixar is back in true form to deliver a fun, meaningful film to warm audience hearts around the world. It's less tear-jerking than previous entries, but it still weaves the Pixar signature great, meaningful narrative that bucks storytelling standard. There are some small but significant character deviations for Buzz and Bo Peep, and not always in a good way. But apart from some mostly harmless missteps it is the sequel fans hoped they could make and feared they wouldn't be able to pull off. Most people probably knew they were going to watch it before reading this, but if you were on the fence, definitely go see it.

Closest comparison: It's like a fresh Toy Story 3 with some of the logistical problems of Finding Dory and a touch of sequelitis.

Setting: Family Fantasy
Plot: Adventure
Tone: Family Adventure

Astounding animation and overall a good plot. I did like it better than the third movie overall, but I felt it was an unnecessary addition to the franchise and destroys all the messages of the previous movies. 
(Spoilers ahead...)
My main issues were as follows:
Firstly it makes no sense to me that Bonnie would play with every toy except Woody, especially after she seemed so interested in playing with him in the third movie. Secondly, the whole voice box thing rubbed me the wrong way how Gabbie Gabbie blackmailed him to get it and not only kept it bu the end of the movie but also got a happy ending... it just kinda felt very off to me. I think it wouldve been more powerful if shed found a kid without needing the voice box... sends a better message of not needing to fix yourself to find a friend. That goes against the message of the precious movies, especially the second where theyd always say Andy will love you no matter what and Woody dealt with his arm being ripped and Andy still wanting to play with him regardless. Lastly, the idea Woody would just leave the entire gang of toys for Bo seems a bit out of character. And goes against the main theme of the other three films. Overall, I did like the movie due to the sheer amazement I had watching Pixars animation quality progress and come such a long way, but story wise it felt more like a fanfiction than something true to what gave Toy Story its heart in the first place and so fell flat.

Widely dubbed as one of cinemas all-time greatest trilogies, Toy Story was an unblemished set of films, never misplacing a step, and while the surprise 4th rendition isn't quite that level of excellence, it's still as charming and heartwarming as ever.

The gang that we grew to love is still very much together, under their new ‘kid' Bonnie. Woody our ever present source of righteousness finds himself struggling to come to terms with no longer being the beloved favourite. Something's never change though, as Woody remains the kindest and loyalist toy you would ever want. He goes the extra mile to ensure that Bonnie doesn't get down in the dumps with her kindergarten blues. This leads to the introduction of our newest member, the surprising engaging ‘Forky'. Several events follow until we end up riding that old movie trope, The Road Trip. 

Slow to get going, the story gets stuck in a loop. It's not till the end where you see the Toy Story you love begin to flourish and blossom, making you feel all those emotions this franchise has made you ever so familiar with. 
Repetition runs rife, woven into the fabric of the narrative. The repetition begins and ends with Forky, the newest member of our toy chest. Suffering from a crisis of identity and belonging Forky seeks refuge in the place he believes he belongs. Thankfully this source of personal irritation is lulled by a tender scene, ran by Woody.

While it may start slow, the opening sequence is quintessential Pixar, a delightful recap (that I was more than grateful for), brimming with warmth and emotion, just lovely storytelling. Quickly catching you up on Bo Peep's initial exit, before her return as a kick-ass, wandering renegade, seeking a life of freedom, which opposes the standard Toy life. 

As for the new characters, they're all good, and there's a few I would've liked to see more of - and had their backstory improved upon. Gabby is a refreshing antagonist for a film targeted towards kids. She operates in the grey area of ‘villains', she is without a doubt an intimidating on-screen presence, but the lines are blurred between good and evil, which is pleasing to see. The other side characters are all good, standouts being Duke Caboom and Bunny and Ducky. Ultimately they're sacrificed as Woody takes centre stage. He dominates the screen time, gobbling it all up. 

I do feel I should acknowledge that this 4th tale of the toys hits on similar beats covered in the first three tales. There is a distinct similarity in how the plot and character actions are bent to progress the story. At times it may feel contrived, but that feeling will be over-run by sheer nostalgia and joy that will never leave these characters.

In Toy Story 3 we all felt like the story had ran its course, and finished perfectly, but we were wrong, Toy Story was finished, but Woody's Story still had legs in it yet, and I'm pleased to say that this 4th installment did a wonderful job of telling and closing his arc, that meant so much to so many.

I watched this movie at the local cinema in Rome, NY. I expected the movie to be really bad after the fantastic ending of Toy Story 3, but it didnt suck as bad as i expected. The animation is fantastic, and is almost photorealistic. However, the story felt lazy to me. The themes of the film contradict eachother. Bo Peep says that having no kid is great and that toys without a kid have a certain freedom. After giving woody a speech about this, Bo Peep helps the doll find a child, and claims that that is the better thing. So what is the theme? That a toy should be loyal to a child or that a toy should fuck their child over and be free? Very confusing. The new characters are either really stupid or not funny at all, and the old characters didnt get shit from pixar. They sat in the r.v. and tricked some grown ass men into thinking that the gps was broken. HOWEVER, the ending saved this movie from 2 stars. The ending was emotional due to great performances by Tim Allen and Tom Hanks. In conclusion, this is deffinately what would have happened after Toy Story 3, but it was not needed for the universe. It was basically a fairly well done cash grab.

You already knew this film was going to rock. It just kept box ticking the whole way through. We get to see Andy again, there's that beautiful transition sequence that Pixar excel at to bring us up to present events and we're back with the gang pretty much where we left off.

So about half hour in I started to wonder about the old characters, the Potato heads seemed mute (I know Ron died but they said they had his dialogue covered, but 3 lines?) Even Rex was unusually quiet and unpanicked. However the new characters seamlessly replaced them and I wasn't left wondering anymore. I loved the introduction of the little cop and then the inevitable dark side in the form of the ventriloquist dummies and the creepy but pretty little talking doll. The stunt guy was a great addition and each of the new guys played a nice part in the overall story telling, not forgetting the 2 stuffed toys from the shooting range. The little alternate reality scenes with them were a genius idea and added yet another layer to the already bulging amount of depth to this film.

The animation was on another level and the realism, although held a bit in check I feel so as to not go full on photo realistic was really lovely and made the whole thing sit as a believable film a whole lot more. I loved the way that although there was this dark threat to the film that is was actually done in a really nice way and the threat was neutralised and weaved itself perfectly into the story and the antagonist became the climax of the film. Before I went in I was wondering when they were going to deliver the emotional punch in the guts and as per the previous film it was almost at the end. I thought I could avoid it, not be affected, or just brush it off somehow but damn, those guys did it again and had me crying in the cinema when the little lost girl picked Dolly up and hugged her. Crikey, these guys know how to deliver that so masterfully and pull all of the invested emotion into a simple scene, leaving you brimming with all sorts of feelings and the unstoppable moist eyes.

So yeah, we went full circle, we learned all about friendships all over again, we had Buzz on another tangent with his inner voice and overall many layers of adult themes crammed into a children's romp. But Pixar know their quarry, these guys are the masters and they can pick and choose the top talent in the world to come and work for them. I noticed the film was directed by an unfamiliar face but clearly the old guard had a huge influence on this movie. I loved it from start to finish, what a feast, what a way to go out, belly laughs, tears and I just can't wait to watch it over and over again like I do with all of Pixar's masterpieces. Simply fantastic!

Just when you think a beloved story has reached the end, completed with a perfectly polishing bookend, there is surprisingly another chapter that takes it further; although questioned whether it is necessary and will it take it further to a new impactful direction – only if it still can be impactful if the franchise is not tired yet. The groundbreaking original "Toy Story" explored the relationship between inanimate object and children, only to discover the former, in plural, that the toys are alive with accustomed feelings that fuels loyalty and the need to be played with. The sentimental resonance is expressed in different ways after each chapter, including the shorts, and the supposedly concluding chapter "Toy Story 4" justified the further continuation with the emotional meaningfulness still ever intact for a more solidifying finale.

Ever since being donated to Bonnie, Andy's former childhood toys are much happier from livelier playtime with the little girl. Woody's rebooted bond with a new kid is instant as he always believes that a toy is always there for the kid, which led him to witness Bonnie's newly-created, crafted toy Forky capturing her young imaginative eyes, but the self-proclaimed trash declared otherwise when refused to be played as a toy. As the family went on a road trip with Bonnie taking the whole gang, it is up to Woody to show Forky the important role he now plays and why he should embrace the new status, but gets soon sidetracked into reuniting with his long-lost friend Bo Peep whose life on the road made her more daring and provides a new insight that will open Woody's eyes.

After how the predecessor ended in remarkable perfection, a continuation would be met with initial doubt. Besides the treated bonus shorts released over the years afterwards in delivering more into the beloved characters' new life, a feature would need to be the final thread to the thematic core. Albeit feeling the somewhat little muddling narrative that fourth chapters tend to pace with in comparison to the previous entries and following up the best, the writing team managed to form ideas and wholesomely delivered, as well in particularly further expressing the relationship between a child and a toy from building to [fully] losing one and a toy finding its purpose. After this film, it has pretty much covered everything over the subject across the span of four films.

Toy Story 4 — Finally saw this movie (about time!). It was really good (Big surprise there *sarcasm*). I was reminded immediately how much I love these characters and this series. The animation in this movie was incredible. The details they put into every little thing is amazing. Just when you think the animation couldn’t get any better, they go ahead and one-up themselves going further and further into the details of everything. This movie was definitely more centered around Woody and BoPeep (and Forky) than any others, which I was fine with, but did have me missing not seeing the other characters quite as much. There were a couple scenes toward the end that got me a little bit teary-eyed, but I still think nothing tops the end of Toy Story 3. That being said, I really enjoyed this movie and think it was a good addition to the series. They could’ve called it quits after Toy Story 3 and I would’ve been happy, but Pixar knows how to handle this series and these characters and  put together a great movie. Toy Story 3 is still my favorite of the series, but Toy Story 4 was really entertaining and addressed some newer themes that kept things feeling fresh and engaging. Go see it if you haven’t! :)

I was initially sceptical about this film, and knowing what went on in production didn't help, so I went into it expecting to be at least a bit disappointed. Then I came out the cinema with a big smile on my face because I was so happy it was made. The animation is the most beautiful I've ever seen both inside and outside of Pixar, it's emotionally deep and complex with funny moments, heartwarming moments, nostalgia, anger, and the bittersweet ending, and while Toy Story 3 was the perfect ending for the franchise, I consider Toy Story 4 to be the perfect ending for Woody. Seeing all these characters back on the big screen was a delight, and all the new characters are everything between hilarious and terrifying with a fantastic villain that from a film making viewpoint is better than Lotso. The only big issue I have with it is that many of the old characters are put to the side, and I can see lovers of Buzz being extremely disappointed in how the film handled him. Still, it was completely necessary, and I admire Pixar for achieving the impossible.

The first half of this movie was great. Well animated, funny, cute. I know my child enjoys the idea of toys having a reality that adults are just to myopic to see but that kids fully enjoy. I thought the movie took a turn for the worse (from 5 stars down to 4) when the story became too much about the toys, and less of the cute interaction between the toys and the humans. Then, it became downright creepy when (spoiler alert) the doll Gabby went psycho on Woody, having her mannequin "goons" on woody to basically harvest his organs (voice box) for her own selfish enterprise. Really, I don't know if other adults picked up on this even though I'm sure the kids didn't. I honestly could not decide if Gabby was supposed to be a villain in this plot, yet the story was told as though she were a sympathetic character. Maybe I'm overthinking this. I think for the kiddos, still a great flick. For the adults, maybe a good opportunity for a restroom break halfway through.

This fourth installment is as good as the other two first films in the franchise, only surpassed by the third. When a new toy called "Forky" joins Woody and the gang, a road trip alongside old and new friends reveals how big the world can be for a toy. The animation was beautiful, the level of creativity in this world of living toys has no limits, the progressive new look of Bo Peep is mesmerizing and the matters of existential crisis and philosophical questions are handled cleverly. With a strong plot, a powerful ending that breaks hearts, a delightful voice cast and a ton of Pixar Easter eggs and references, this was a very enyojable time.

Toy Story 4 is a feminist rom/com—a romantic comedy in the classic mold with a feminist twist.

Indeed, the film "makes the couple" a whopping 3 times: Woody (the reluctant male who needs to be persuaded to take the plunge) and Bo Peep; Forky and (for a better word) Knifey, the "trash" twosome whose coming together as the credits roll is both unexpected and delightful, a moment of sheer cinematic bliss; and Gabby Gabby and the "lost girl."

Even though Woody is the primary protagonist, and several new male toys are introduced, "Toy Story 4" goes beyond the addition of a female toy here and there (e.g. cowgirl Jessie in "Toy Story 2"); this is the franchise's feminist film. 

Woody is fond of Bo Beep and she of him. But Bo's strengths are many and threaten to overwhelm and displace Woody's desire. She's a fiercely independent feminist, having been "on her own," beyond the security of a child's bedroom, for 7 years. She's an athlete and a warrior, using her hook as a both a weapon and climbing device. Bo and other independent toys travel around in a mechanical skunk. These "Independent Toys," which exist somewhere between "Lost Toys" and "Toys who have a Kid," are a new category for the franchise.

Duke Caboom, Ducky and Bunny are solid and funny additions to the "Toy Story" crew, but on the whole the cast is too large and dispenses with too many familiar characters to achieve the kind of focus that shaped previous editions.

These caveats aside, "Toy Story 4" is almost as good as its predecessors - and that's saying something.

If the Toy Story saga was a movie, Toy Story 4 would be the over joyous, emotional, epilogue to the franchise. This movie deals with moving on after your very existence is questioned, and how to find a new purpose when there seems be a lack of hope around you. The movie shocks you to the core, but is a philosophical, emotional roller-coaster that is completely worth the ride.

Excellent movie, excellent animation. Absolutely loved the new characters Duke Caboom, ducky, bunny, and gabby gabby. The skunk mobile was super creative and a hilarious way for the toys to move around. Bo Peep was phenomenal, literally the best version of her I think we'll ever see. This was clearly a movie all about woody and I gotta say I am happy for him for what he chose at the end but at the same time I'm upset that they split up the group. I'm also a bit upset that the majority of the older characters didn't get much screen time at all. This movie could easily be setting up new beginnings for a 5th iteration in the franchise. Only time will tell but I'm game to return to these characters again.

It was cute, but of all the things they could have done with this movie they introduced us to a fork??? Every toy story introduced us to a new TOY, but nope not this one we got a fork. I kind of got over the fact that her new best thing in the whole world was a fork, but then at the end when she came back from her first day of first grade she brought home a knife. 🤦🏽‍♀️ I was confused. They would have been better off letting her create a spoon, but who let a first grader decorate and play with a knife, even if it was plastic?

Not a fan of the ending.

Toy Story 4 was average at best. As someone whose first ever film was the original story and someone who saw Toy Story 3 in cinemas just before I started university (watching Andy head off for college), I consider myself very much of the Toy Story generation. This film really feels like it's forgotten it's older fans and has moved on to a much younger audience, which is quite sad. It lacked the usual charm of a Pixar movie that sees jokes for both children and adults. Scenes are repetitive and cover a lot of the same information multiple times. 

The toy cast list has almost been tripled and yet next to no time is spent with any character that isn't Woody or Bo. Even staple characters like Buzz and Jessie are very much sidelined. So many characters are introduced and given next to no screen time.

It's sad to see Toy Story end this way after, what I consider, a perfect ending to their third instalment.
